content: The Act titled "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, it includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to recall retired judges for further service in accordance with Section 7257 of title 38, United States Code. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service by providing an irrevocable notice to the chief judge or clerk of the Court. A retired judge is defined as someone who retires from the Court under specific sections of the law, and a recall-eligible retired judge is one who has given such notice. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service by providing an irrevocable notice to the chief judge or clerk of the Court. A recall-eligible retired judge is defined as a retired judge who has given such notice, and the chief judge may recall them for a period not exceeding 90 days as needed. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service by providing an irrevocable notice to the chief judge or clerk of the Court. A recall-eligible retired judge may be recalled for up to 90 days per calendar year with their consent, not exceeding a total of 180 days. If a recall-eligible retired judge is recalled but declines to serve (except due to disability), they will be removed from recall status. A disabled recall-eligible retired judge unable to serve further will also be removed from recall status. A recall-eligible retired judge who becomes permanently disabled and unable to serve further will be removed from recall status. A recalled retired judge can exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay of a recall-eligible retired judge is specified in the relevant section. A retired judge recalled under this section can exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled judge varies based on retirement status and is specified in the relevant section. The judge serving in recall status receives pay at the rate of an active judge, minus their annuity under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5. Retired judges recalled under this section have the same powers and duties as active judges. The section allows retired judges under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 to serve as reemployed annuitants. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's service. Fractional parts of a year less than 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. The retired pay of a recall-eligible retired judge under section 7257 of title 38, United States Code, shall be the pay of a judge of the court. The retired pay of a judge removed from recall status due to disability shall be the pay of a judge of the court. If a judge did not provide notice of availability for service in a recalled status at retirement, their retired pay will be based on their rate of pay at retirement. If a judge was recall-eligible and removed from recall status, their retired pay will be based on the pay of a judge of the court. The retired pay of a judge removed from recall status due to disability shall be the pay of a judge of the court. If a judge was recall-eligible and removed from recall status, their retired pay will be based on the pay of a judge at the time of removal from recall status. Cost-of-living adjustments provided by law in annuities under civil service retirement laws shall apply to retired pay. Cost-of-Living Adjustments: A cost-of-living adjustment in retired pay applies only to retired pay computed under specific conditions. If the adjustment would exceed the annual rate of pay for a retired chief judge, it may be adjusted accordingly. Cost-of-Living Adjustments: If a cost-of-living adjustment would result in retired pay exceeding the annual rate of pay for a retired chief judge, the adjustment can only be made to equal that annual rate of pay. For retired judges other than chief judges, adjustments are limited to prevent exceeding the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Cost-of-Living Adjustments: For retired judges (excluding chief judges), adjustments are limited to prevent their retired pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Cost-of-Living Adjustments: Retired judges' pay is limited to prevent it from exceeding the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. If a retired or reserve member of a uniformed service becomes a judge, their retired pay is suspended during active service on the court but resumes upon retirement. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. Section 7299 of title 38, United States Code, limits the activities of retired judges from the Court in practicing law to represent clients making claims for veterans' benefits against the United States or its agencies. Retired judges forfeit their retired pay for a period starting when the representation begins until one year after it ends. Retired judges representing clients for veterans' benefits forfeit retired pay for one year after representation ends. SEC. 7. EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY FOR CURRENT JUDGES IN ORDER TO PROVIDE FOR STAGGERED TERMS OF JUDGES. Retirement Authorized: One eligible judge may retire annually from 1999 to 2003. Eligible Judges are associate judges of the US Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims with 10 years of service, retired pay election, 20 years of service, and minimum age of 55. An eligible judge may retire annually if they have made a retired pay election, have at least 20 years of service, and are at least 55 years old. If multiple judges are eligible in a year, the one with the most seniority on the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can retire. An eligible judge can retire annually if they meet certain criteria, including having at least 20 years of service and being at least 55 years old. The judge with the most seniority on the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can retire if multiple judges are eligible in a year. The judge who is eligible to retire in a specific year shall provide written notice to the President and the chief judge by April 1 of that year. An eligible judge can retire annually by providing written notice to the President and chief judge by April 1 of that year. The retirement date must be specified and the notice is irrevocable. The judge shall retire during the fiscal year in which notice is given, not earlier than 90 days after providing the notice. A judge eligible for retirement must provide written notice by April 1 of the year, with the retirement date specified and irrevocable. The retirement shall occur during the fiscal year of notice, not earlier than 90 days after providing it. The retired judge is considered as retired under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code. A judge retiring must give written notice by April 1 with an irrevocable retirement date during the fiscal year. The retired judge is considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay is determined by specific provisions in section 7296(c)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay for judges is determined by specific provisions in section 7296(c)(1) of title 38, United States Code, based on years of service and age. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to specific provisions in section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. An adjustment in annuities under civil service retirement laws also applies to retired pay for recall-eligible judges under section 7257 of title 38, United States Code. The amendment in section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code, includes a provision for determining the present value by an actuary for payments from the retirement fund under subsection (b) for recall-eligible judges.
